SENT.plain: Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) can be difficult to diagnose because of its wide spectrum of clinical manifestations
Its diagnosis may be further complicated when patients initially present with acute subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)
We report on four patients with SAH revealing a CVT and discuss the role of imaging for diagnostic and pretherapeutic workup
In three women and one man presenting with severe headaches, images initially suggested SAH with no associated parenchymal bleeding
In all patients, SAH involved the sulci of the convexity and spared the basal cisterns
Digital subtracted angiography showed occlusion of intracranial venous sinuses but did not reveal any other cause of SAH
All patients improved with anticoagulant therapy
Risk factors for CVT and SAH, namely, head trauma and oral contraception, were identified in two patients
These cases highlight the fact SAH may reveal a CVT, which should be considered in the diagnostic workup of SAH, especially when the basal cisterns are not involved
